categories.name: Metaphysics
categories.description: Being, existence, causation, and the fundamental structure of reality

categories.name: Epistemology
categories.description: Knowledge, truth, and the powers and limits of human reason

categories.name: Logic
categories.description: Principles of valid reasoning, logical demonstration, and rational inference

categories.name: Theology
categories.description: Rational study of God, divine attributes, and religious truth

categories.name: Ethics
categories.description: Moral principles, natural law, and the human good

categories.name: Philosophical Anthropology
categories.description: Human nature, the soul, personal identity, and human destiny

categories.name: Philosophy of Mind
categories.description: Consciousness, free will, and the relationship between mind and body

categories.name: Philosophy of Language
categories.description: Meaning, communication, and the relationship between language and reality

categories.name: Philosophy of Mathematics
categories.description: Mathematical truth, necessity, and the relationship to physical reality

categories.name: Philosophy of Science
categories.description: Scientific method, natural laws, and the structure of scientific knowledge

categories.name: Aesthetics
categories.description: Beauty, art, and aesthetic experience

categories.name: Political Philosophy
categories.description: Government, justice, rights, and political obligation

categories.name: Philosophy of Culture
categories.description: Cultural development, tradition, and social meaning

categories.name: Philosophy of Biology
categories.description: Life, evolution, and biological explanation

categories.name: Philosophy of Social Science
categories.description: Understanding human behavior and social phenomena

categories.name: Philosophy of Technology
categories.description: Technology's role in human life and society

categories.name: Environmental Philosophy
categories.description: Human relationship with nature and environmental ethics

categories.name: Existentialism
categories.description: Meaning, freedom, and authentic existence

categories.name: Philosophy of History
categories.description: Understanding historical processes and meaning

categories.name: Philosophy of Economics
categories.description: Economic systems, value, and market relationships

categories.name: Philosophy of Religion
categories.description: Religious truth, faith, reason, and inter-religious dialogue

nodes.title: Something exists
nodes.description: At minimum, I exist as a thinking being. This is self-evident and cannot be coherently denied.

nodes.title: Principle of non-contradiction
nodes.description: Something cannot both be and not be in the same respect at the same time. Contradictory statements cannot both be true.

nodes.title: Senses provide knowledge of reality
nodes.description: Our senses, though sometimes mistaken, generally provide reliable information about the external world.

nodes.title: Principle of causation
nodes.description: Every effect has a cause. Nothing comes into being without a sufficient reason for its existence.

nodes.title: Change and motion occur
nodes.description: We observe that things change, move, and are actualized from potency to act. This is evident to our senses.

nodes.title: Consciousness exists
nodes.description: I am aware of my own thoughts, feelings, and experiences. This immediate awareness cannot be doubted.

nodes.title: Memory is generally reliable
nodes.description: My memories of past experiences, while not infallible, provide meaningful continuity of personal identity.

nodes.title: Other minds exist
nodes.description: Other humans possess consciousness and inner experiences similar to my own.

nodes.title: Language conveys meaning
nodes.description: Words and symbols can successfully communicate ideas and concepts between minds.

nodes.title: Reason can discover truth
nodes.description: Logical reasoning and rational inquiry can lead to genuine understanding of reality.

nodes.title: Mathematics describes reality
nodes.description: Mathematical patterns and relationships correspond to structures in the physical world.

nodes.title: Time exists and flows
nodes.description: Events occur in temporal sequence, with a meaningful distinction between past, present, and future.

nodes.title: Space exists as extension
nodes.description: Physical objects exist in spatial relationships with measurable distances and dimensions.

nodes.title: Moral distinctions are real
nodes.description: Some actions are genuinely better or worse than others, not merely matters of opinion.

nodes.title: Beauty exists objectively
nodes.description: Some things possess genuine aesthetic value that transcends mere personal preference.

nodes.title: Truth is discoverable
nodes.description: Reality has a definite structure that can be progressively understood through inquiry.

nodes.title: The future is partially open
nodes.description: While constrained by natural laws, genuine possibilities exist for different outcomes.

nodes.title: Human dignity has intrinsic worth
nodes.description: Every human being possesses inherent value that cannot be reduced to utility or function.

nodes.title: Natural patterns exhibit order
nodes.description: The universe displays consistent regularities and laws that govern natural phenomena.

nodes.title: Suffering is genuinely bad
nodes.description: Pain and suffering constitute real evils, not merely subjective preferences.

nodes.title: An external world exists
nodes.description: Given that our senses are generally reliable and we observe consistent patterns, there exists a world of material objects external to our minds.
nodes.conclusion: Material reality exists independently of our consciousness

nodes.title: Scientific method reveals truth
nodes.description: Systematic observation, hypothesis formation, and experimental testing provide reliable knowledge about natural phenomena.
nodes.conclusion: Science discovers genuine facts about reality

nodes.title: Personal identity persists through time
nodes.description: Despite physical and mental changes, each person maintains a continuous identity across their lifetime.
nodes.conclusion: The self endures as a unified entity

nodes.title: Causal series exist in nature
nodes.description: Since change occurs and every effect has a cause, there exist chains of causation connecting events in the natural world.
nodes.conclusion: Reality is structured by causal relationships

nodes.title: A first cause is necessary
nodes.description: Since infinite regress of causes is impossible, there must be a first uncaused cause that explains the existence of all other things.
nodes.conclusion: A first uncaused cause must exist

nodes.title: Communication enables knowledge
nodes.description: Through language and symbols, humans can share discoveries and build cumulative understanding beyond individual experience.

nodes.title: Mathematical truths are universal
nodes.description: Mathematical relationships hold necessarily and apply across all possible worlds and contexts.

nodes.title: Moral progress is possible
nodes.description: Societies can genuinely improve their ethical practices and move closer to objective moral truths.
nodes.conclusion: Ethics involves discovery, not mere invention

nodes.title: Free will exists
nodes.description: Humans possess genuine agency and can make meaningful choices that are not entirely determined by prior causes.

nodes.title: Aesthetic experience reveals value
nodes.description: The appreciation of beauty provides genuine insight into objective features of reality worth preserving and creating.
nodes.conclusion: Art and beauty have cognitive significance

nodes.title: Natural law governs physical events
nodes.description: The consistent patterns observed in nature reflect genuine laws that constrain and predict physical behavior.
nodes.conclusion: The universe operates by discoverable principles

nodes.title: Human rights are universal
nodes.description: All humans possess fundamental rights that transcend cultural differences and political arrangements.
nodes.conclusion: Basic moral claims apply to all persons

nodes.title: Truth correspondence to reality
nodes.description: True statements accurately describe how things actually are, independent of what anyone believes about them.

nodes.title: Rational discourse can resolve disagreement
nodes.description: Through careful reasoning and evidence, people with different views can sometimes reach genuine agreement about disputed questions.

nodes.title: Evil problem challenges perfect being
nodes.description: The existence of genuine suffering and moral evil creates difficulties for belief in an all-powerful, all-good creator.

nodes.title: Mental states affect physical states
nodes.description: Conscious decisions and mental events can influence bodily behavior and physical processes.

nodes.title: Emergent properties arise from complexity
nodes.description: When simple components organize in complex ways, genuinely new properties can emerge that were not present in the parts alone.

nodes.title: Cultural evolution shapes human nature
nodes.description: Human practices, institutions, and ways of thinking evolve through cultural transmission and collective learning.

nodes.title: Phenomenology reveals experience structure
nodes.description: Careful attention to the structure of conscious experience reveals essential features of how reality appears to minds.

nodes.title: Social contract creates political obligation
nodes.description: Political authority becomes legitimate when citizens consent to be governed in exchange for protection and mutual benefit.

nodes.title: Virtue enables human flourishing
nodes.description: Developing excellent character traits leads to fulfillment and contributes to the common good of communities.

nodes.title: Evolutionary process explains biological complexity
nodes.description: Natural selection operating over long time periods can produce the intricate adaptations observed in living organisms.

nodes.title: Interpretive understanding differs from explanation
nodes.description: Human actions and cultural phenomena require interpretive understanding that goes beyond causal explanation of natural events.

nodes.title: Technology extends human capabilities
nodes.description: Tools and machines amplify human powers of perception, action, and computation, enabling new forms of flourishing.

nodes.title: Environmental ethics constrains human action
nodes.description: Humans have moral obligations to preserve natural systems and consider the welfare of non-human life.

nodes.title: Artificial intelligence raises consciousness questions
nodes.description: As machines become more sophisticated, fundamental questions arise about whether they could possess genuine understanding or awareness.

nodes.title: Global ethics transcends local customs
nodes.description: In an interconnected world, moral consideration must extend beyond tribal, national, and cultural boundaries.

nodes.title: Meaning emerges from purpose and connection
nodes.description: Life's meaning comes from pursuing worthwhile goals, forming relationships, and contributing to something greater than oneself.
nodes.conclusion: Meaning can be found in finite existence

nodes.title: Historical understanding requires empathy
nodes.description: To understand past events and peoples, we must imaginatively enter into their worldviews while maintaining critical perspective.
nodes.conclusion: History involves both empathy and judgment

nodes.title: Future generations have moral standing
nodes.description: Present actions that significantly affect future persons carry moral weight, even though those people do not yet exist.

nodes.title: Divine revelation is possible
nodes.description: If God exists, it is conceivable that divine truth could be communicated to human beings through various means.

nodes.title: Historical testimony can convey truth
nodes.description: Reliable witnesses can transmit knowledge of past events, including extraordinary ones, through consistent testimony.

nodes.title: Perfect being is conceivable
nodes.description: The concept of a maximally great being - possessing all perfections - is coherent and meaningful.

nodes.title: Contingent beings require explanation
nodes.description: Everything that exists but could fail to exist requires a reason for its existence rather than non-existence.

nodes.title: Degrees of perfection exist
nodes.description: We observe varying degrees of goodness, truth, and nobility among beings, implying a standard of comparison.

nodes.title: Purpose guides natural processes
nodes.description: Natural things exhibit goal-directed behavior and functions that serve ends beyond mere mechanical causation.

nodes.title: Economic exchange creates value
nodes.description: Voluntary trade between parties generally benefits both, creating mutual value and improving human welfare.

nodes.title: Private property rights exist
nodes.description: Individuals can legitimately acquire exclusive rights to use and transfer material goods through labor and exchange.

nodes.title: Labor has intrinsic dignity
nodes.description: Human work possesses inherent worth beyond mere economic value, contributing to personal development and social good.

nodes.title: Competition improves outcomes
nodes.description: When people compete to provide goods and services, this generally leads to better quality and lower prices for consumers.

nodes.title: Religious experience is meaningful
nodes.description: Encounters with the sacred or transcendent can provide genuine insight and spiritual knowledge, not mere subjective feeling.

nodes.title: Multiple truth sources exist
nodes.description: Truth can be discovered through reason, experience, testimony, and potentially divine revelation across different domains.

nodes.title: Cultural diversity enriches understanding
nodes.description: Different cultural perspectives and traditions can contribute valuable insights about human nature and the good life.

nodes.title: Social cooperation enables flourishing
nodes.description: Humans achieve greater individual and collective good through coordinated effort than through isolated action.

nodes.title: Innovation drives progress
nodes.description: Creative discovery and technological development can genuinely improve human living conditions and expand possibilities.

nodes.title: God exists as prime mover
nodes.description: Since motion occurs and infinite regress is impossible, there must be a first unmoved mover that actualizes all potential.
nodes.conclusion: A prime mover exists, and this we call God

edges.description: Everything moved is moved by another

nodes.title: God exists as first efficient cause
nodes.description: The chain of efficient causation requires a first cause that is itself uncaused, since infinite causal regress is impossible.
nodes.conclusion: A first efficient cause exists, which is God

nodes.title: God exists as necessary being
nodes.description: Contingent beings require a necessary being for their existence, since an infinite chain of contingent beings cannot account for existence itself.
nodes.conclusion: A necessary being exists, which is God

nodes.title: God exists as most perfect being
nodes.description: The degrees of perfection we observe require a most perfect being as their measure and source.
nodes.conclusion: A maximally perfect being exists, which is God

nodes.title: God exists as intelligent designer
nodes.description: The evident purpose and design in nature requires an intelligent cause capable of ordering things toward their ends.
nodes.conclusion: An intelligent designer exists, which is God

nodes.title: Christ's divinity is historically credible
nodes.description: The historical evidence for Jesus Christ's extraordinary claims, miracles, and resurrection provides reasonable grounds for believing in his divine nature.
nodes.conclusion: Jesus Christ is both human and divine

nodes.title: Trinity explains divine nature
nodes.description: The doctrine of Trinity - one God in three persons - coherently explains how God can be both transcendent and intimately involved in creation.

edges.description: Perfect being encompasses unity and relationship

nodes.title: Religious truth transcends but includes reason
nodes.description: While divine mysteries exceed human comprehension, they do not contradict reason but fulfill and elevate it.

nodes.title: Religious coexistence requires mutual respect
nodes.description: Different religious traditions can coexist peacefully while maintaining their distinctive truth claims through dialogue and mutual understanding.
nodes.conclusion: Pluralistic society can accommodate religious differences

nodes.title: Natural law provides universal moral foundation
nodes.description: Moral principles discoverable by reason provide a basis for ethical dialogue across religious and cultural differences.

nodes.title: Free markets coordinate economic activity
nodes.description: Market prices and voluntary exchange enable efficient allocation of scarce resources without central planning.

nodes.title: Property rights protect human dignity
nodes.description: The ability to acquire, use, and transfer property provides security and enables personal development and family care.

nodes.title: Entrepreneurship drives innovation and progress
nodes.description: Individual initiative in creating new products, services, and methods of production benefits society through innovation and job creation.

nodes.title: Economic inequality reflects diverse contributions
nodes.description: Differences in income and wealth often correspond to differences in productivity, innovation, and value creation for society.

nodes.title: Worker dignity requires fair compensation
nodes.description: Labor's intrinsic worth demands that workers receive wages sufficient for human dignity and family support.
nodes.conclusion: Just wage principles constrain market outcomes

nodes.title: Economic systems must serve human flourishing
nodes.description: Economic arrangements should be evaluated by whether they enable people to develop their capacities and contribute to the common good.

nodes.title: Global trade benefits all participants
nodes.description: International exchange allows countries to specialize in their comparative advantages, increasing total wealth and opportunities.

nodes.title: Economic regulation serves legitimate purposes
nodes.description: Government intervention in markets can be justified to correct failures, protect vulnerable parties, and ensure fair competition.
nodes.conclusion: Mixed economy balances freedom and justice

nodes.title: Wealth creation reduces poverty
nodes.description: Economic growth and innovation provide the resources needed to improve living conditions for the poorest members of society.

nodes.title: Environmental limits constrain economic growth
nodes.description: Infinite economic expansion on a finite planet requires attention to sustainability and stewardship of natural resources.

nodes.title: Technology shapes human relationships
nodes.description: Digital communication and social media alter how people connect, share information, and form communities in fundamental ways.
nodes.conclusion: Technological literacy is essential for flourishing

nodes.title: Artificial intelligence raises ethical questions
nodes.description: As AI systems become more capable, questions about consciousness, moral status, and human-AI relationships become increasingly urgent.
nodes.conclusion: AI ethics requires careful philosophical analysis

nodes.title: Cultural authenticity has value
nodes.description: Traditional practices and ways of life possess intrinsic worth that should be preserved alongside progress and development.

nodes.title: Democratic participation requires civic virtue
nodes.description: Self-government succeeds only when citizens possess the knowledge, skills, and character needed for responsible participation.

nodes.title: Climate change demands global cooperation
nodes.description: Environmental challenges transcending national boundaries require coordinated international action and shared responsibility.

nodes.title: Mental health affects human flourishing
nodes.description: Psychological well-being is a genuine component of human happiness that deserves attention in personal and social policy.

nodes.title: Scientific materialism has explanatory limits
nodes.description: While scientific method reveals important truths, conscious experience and moral values cannot be fully reduced to physical processes.

nodes.title: Postmodern skepticism undermines itself
nodes.description: Extreme relativism about truth and knowledge cannot consistently account for its own claims or enable meaningful dialogue.

nodes.title: Social media affects democratic discourse
nodes.description: Digital platforms change how information spreads and how people form political opinions, with significant effects on democratic participation.
nodes.conclusion: Digital literacy is essential for democracy

nodes.title: Identity politics reflects human sociality
nodes.description: People naturally form group identities and loyalties, which can serve beneficial purposes while also creating division and conflict.
nodes.conclusion: Identity must be balanced with universal values

nodes.title: Educational institutions shape cultural transmission
nodes.description: Schools and universities play crucial roles in passing on knowledge, values, and cultural practices to new generations.
nodes.conclusion: Educational philosophy has broad social impact

nodes.title: Bioethics addresses human dignity in medicine
nodes.description: Medical advances raise fundamental questions about life, death, human enhancement, and the proper treatment of human beings.

nodes.title: Intergenerational solidarity requires sacrifice
nodes.description: Current generations must sometimes accept costs to ensure that future people inherit a world capable of supporting human flourishing.

nodes.title: Religious freedom protects human conscience
nodes.description: The capacity for transcendent meaning and worship is fundamental to human nature and deserves protection from coercive interference.
nodes.conclusion: Religious liberty is a basic human right

nodes.title: Work provides meaning beyond compensation
nodes.description: Human labor contributes to personal identity, social contribution, and sense of purpose in ways that transcend mere economic exchange.
nodes.conclusion: Employment policy should consider human fulfillment
